items.title: Agentic AI Startup AMT Aims to Be ‘Google Adwords for Influencers,’ Raises Seed Round
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- AMT raised $3.5 million in a seed funding round led by NFX to simplify influencer marketing through AI.
- The AI agent, Lyra, can autonomously communicate with influencers for booking campaigns and managing relationships.
- AMT claims its platform reduces the average time to secure an influencer partnership from nine hours to five minutes.
- The influencer market is projected to be worth $266.92 billion in 2025, highlighting the demand for efficient marketing solutions.

items.title: Researchers name several countries as potential Paragon spyware customers
items.summary:
- Six countries suspected to be customers of Paragon Solutions: Australia, Canada, Cyprus, Denmark, Israel, and Singapore.
- Report published by The Citizen Lab identifies the governments as potential Paragon spyware deployments.
- WhatsApp reported targeting around 90 users with Paragon spyware in January, causing a scandal in Italy.
- Paragon claims to distinguish itself as a responsible spyware vendor compared to NSO Group.
- U.S. venture capital AE Industrial Partners acquired Paragon for at least $500 million in 2024.
- Citizen Lab mapped server infrastructure linked to Paragon's spyware tool named Graphite, identifying customer countries based on digital certificates.
- Paragon's spyware reportedly targets specific apps on devices without needing user interaction, making detection more challenging.

items.title: Shopify transfers its US listing from the NYSE to the Nasdaq
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- Shopify is moving its U.S. stock listing from the NYSE to the Nasdaq, effective March 31.
- The removal of its Class A shares from the NYSE is set for March 28, with no change to its Toronto Stock Exchange listing.
- The company recently reported Q4 2024 revenues of $2.8 billion, a 31% increase year-on-year, with a market cap of $121 billion.

items.title: Academics accuse AI startups of co-opting peer review for publicity
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Controversy surrounds AI-generated studies submitted to the ICLR conference, raising ethical questions about peer review.
- Three AI labs (Sakana, Intology, Autoscience) generated studies; Sakana informed ICLR, while Intology and Autoscience did not.
- Academics express concern over the misuse of peer review, arguing it undermines the volunteer efforts of human reviewers.

items.title: Prezent raises $20M to build AI for slide decks
items.author: Rajat Mishra, Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Prezent has raised $20 million to enhance its AI for generating slide decks.
- Founded in 2021 by Rajat Mishra, the Los Altos-based startup targets biopharma and tech industries, serving around 150 Fortune 2000 companies.
- The funding will enable expansion into financial services and manufacturing markets as well as geographical growth in Europe, Japan, and Singapore.

items.title: US paid music subscribers cross 100 million mark for the first time
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- The U.S. reached 100 million paid subscribers for music streaming services in 2024, according to a report by [RIAA](https://www.riaa.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/RIAA-2024Year-End-Revenue-Report.pdf).
- This is an increase from 96.8 million in 2023, reflecting a year-on-year growth of approximately 3%.
- Spotify holds a 36% market share in the U.S., followed by Apple Music at 30.7%.
- Streaming revenue accounted for 84% of total music revenue in 2024, equating to $14.9 billion, with paid subscriptions generating $11.7 billion, a 5% increase from the previous year.
- Pricing increases from streaming services like Spotify, Apple Music, and YouTube may have contributed to the higher revenues.

items.title: Aletiq secures $6.5M for its SaaS tool focused on product lifecycle management
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Aletiq has secured €6 million ($6.5 million) in funding led by Point Nine.
- The startup focuses on developing SaaS-based product lifecycle management (PLM) software for industrial sectors like aerospace and automotive.
- Aletiq aims to provide an intuitive and quickly deployable solution, differentiating itself from existing complex PLM systems.

items.title: Factorial, a HR unicorn, snaps up $120M from General Catalyst to boost sales and marketing
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Factorial, based in Barcelona, raised $120 million from General Catalyst for sales and marketing initiatives.
- The company experienced significant growth, with 13,000 paying businesses and sixfold revenue increase over the past year.
- This funding is a non-dilutive loan from General Catalyst's Customer Value fund, intended to help boost Factorial's go-to-market strategy, not an equity investment.
- The funds come amid legal challenges in the HR sector, specifically involving competitors Deel and Rippling.
- Factorial has previously raised $200 million from General Catalyst under similar non-dilutive terms, indicating strong investor interest in its growth potential.

items.title: A comprehensive list of 2025 tech layoffs
items.summary:
- In 2025, over 22,000 tech workers have lost their jobs, with 16,084 layoffs occurring in February alone.
- Siemens to lay off approximately 5,600 jobs globally, focusing on automation and electric vehicle segment.
- HelloFresh plans to cut 273 jobs in Texas as part of a site consolidation.
- Notable layoffs include 340 at Wayfair and 2,500 at HPE due to financial adjustments.
- Major companies such as NASA and TikTok also announced job cuts.

items.title: Trump Fires FTC Commissioners, Setting Up a Legal Battle
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- President Trump fired two Democratic members of the FTC, Rebecca Kelly Slaughter and Alvaro Bedoya.
- This action challenges a 1935 Supreme Court precedent that protects FTC commissioners from being fired without "good cause."
- Slaughter described the firings as "illegal," claiming they violate statutory language and Court precedent.
- The FTC is responsible for enforcing consumer protection and antitrust laws, and typically has five members.

items.title: Nvidia and Google DeepMind will help power Disney’s cute robots
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Nvidia collaborates with Disney Research and Google DeepMind to develop Newton, a physics engine for robotics.
- Newton will be used to power Disney's next-generation entertainment robots, including Star Wars-inspired BDX droids.
- An open-source version of Newton is set to release later in 2025.
- Disney plans to showcase its robots at theme parks starting next year, citing readiness due to Newton.
- Newton helps robots handle complex tasks and enhances interactivity with deformable objects.
- The engine is compatible with Google DeepMind’s tools and technologies for robotic development.
- Nvidia announced other products at GTC 2025, including Groot N1, a foundation model for humanoid robots.

items.title: JD Vance claims freeing AI from regulation is good for American workers and tech innovators
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
• Vice President JD Vance emphasized AI and tech innovations benefiting both populists and tech investors at the Andreessen Horowitz American Dynamism Summit in Washington, D.C.
• Vance noted that fears of AI replacing jobs overlook that innovation often creates higher-paying jobs, citing the historical example of bank tellers displaced by ATMs.
• He criticized past government actions and proposed fewer regulations on AI to stimulate tech innovation while suggesting adjustments to trade and immigration policies to discourage offshoring.

items.title: Elon Musk’s DOGE leadership likely violates constitution’s appointments clause, judge says
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- A federal judge, Theodore Chuang, ruled that Elon Musk's leadership of the Department of Government Efficiency likely violates the U.S. Constitution’s appointments clause.
- Chuang's opinion was made in response to a lawsuit from workers at the USAID, suggesting Musk acts as DOGE's head despite being labeled as a special advisor.
- The ruling emphasizes that Musk has exerted authority that only a properly appointed officer can exercise, and it orders the restoration of certain USAID operations, restricting further dismantling by Musk and DOGE.

items.title: New $5M deep tech fund aims to lure founders from universities
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Critical Venture Partners has launched a $5 million fund targeting young founders from universities.
- The fund aims to address major issues like climate change and healthcare, offering investments between $50,000 and $250,000.
- The firm is collaborating with Yope to host a $100,000 startup competition to attract new talent.
- It has already invested in three startups focusing on innovative solutions such as CO₂ transformation and waste metal recovery.

items.title: NASA astronauts return from long Space Station stay prompted by Boeing problems
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Sunita Williams and Barry Wilmore returned to Earth after a nine-month stay on the ISS due to Boeing Starliner's issues.
- They splashed down in the Gulf of Mexico in a SpaceX Dragon capsule after a 17-hour return journey.
- The mission duration was extended because of leaks and thruster problems with the Starliner spacecraft.
- Initially launched in June 2024, the mission was meant to help Boeing compete with SpaceX's historic crewed flights.
- NASA and SpaceX coordinated to bring the astronauts back early in 2025 to avoid short-staffing the ISS.
- Elon Musk claimed he offered to bring them home sooner, a statement disputed by former NASA officials and White House sources.

items.title: What Tesla can and can’t do in California with its new passenger transportation permit
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Tesla received a permit from the California Public Utilities Commission to operate a transportation service.
- The permit does not cover autonomous vehicle testing or deployment and is different from ride-hailing companies' permits.
- Tesla plans to use the permit initially to transport employees and will notify the CPUC when it starts transporting the public.
- The company does not have permits for driverless rides in California yet but plans to launch a robotaxi service in Austin, Texas, in June with the “unsupervised” version of its Full Self-Driving software.

items.title: An AI model from over a decade ago sparked Nvidia’s investment in autonomous vehicles
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- During the GTC 2025 conference, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang highlighted the influence of AlexNet on their focus on autonomous vehicles.
- AlexNet, created by Alex Krizhevsky, Ilya Sutskever, and Geoffrey Hinton, achieved 84.7% accuracy in the ImageNET competition in 2012, reviving interest in deep learning.
- Nvidia has partnered with numerous automakers, including GM, Tesla, and others, providing GPU technology for self-driving cars and digital twin technology for factories.

items.title: Nvidia announces two ‘personal AI supercomputers’
items.author: Becca
items.summary:
- Nvidia revealed new AI personal supercomputers, DGX Spark and DGX Station, at GTC 2025.
- The DGX Spark offers up to 1,000 trillion operations per second using the GB10 Grace Blackwell Superchip.
- DGX Station will feature a GB300 Grace Blackwell Ultra Desktop Superchip with 784GB of memory, launching later this year.

items.title: FTC removes posts critical of big tech from its website
items.summary:
- The FTC has removed over 300 blog posts from its website published under former chair Lina Khan.
- These posts included criticisms of significant tech companies like Amazon and Microsoft regarding customer data handling.
- The removal may violate government data handling laws and aligns with the Trump administration's campaign to eliminate certain words from public documents.

items.title: GM teams up with Nvidia to bring AI to robots, factories, and self-driving cars
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- General Motors (GM) partners with Nvidia to integrate AI across its operations, including factories and self-driving cars.
- Nvidia will supply AI infrastructure, including GPUs, and assist GM in building custom AI systems.
- GM to utilize Nvidia Omniverse with Cosmos for training AI models to enhance factory design and robotics.
- The collaboration aims to create a digital twin of factories to test production processes.
- GM is also using Nvidia Drive AGX for advanced driver-assistance and safety features in future vehicles.

items.title: Nvidia debuts Groot N1, a foundation model for humanoid robotics
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Nvidia announces Groot N1, an AI foundation model for humanoid robotics at GTC 2025 in San Jose.
- Groot N1 features a dual system architecture for 'thinking fast and slow', inspired by human cognition.
- The model expands from Nvidia's Project Groot to cover humanoid robots in various form factors.
- Groot N1 is available as open source with simulation frameworks and blueprints for synthetic training data.
- CEO Jensen Huang states that 'the age of generalist robotics is here.'
- Other companies like X1 and Figure are aiming to create general-purpose humanoid robots, with technology advancing towards realistic mass production.

items.title: Here’s why Google pitched its $32B Wiz acquisition as ‘multicloud’
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Google announced its acquisition of security startup Wiz for $32 billion, positioning it as a multicloud offering.
- Wiz has an annual revenue rate of $700 million and was on track to reach $1 billion before the acquisition news.
- Google aims to retain Wiz’s existing customers who may not exclusively use Google Cloud, as many operate in a hybrid cloud environment.
- The acquisition raises concerns about regulatory challenges, but Google’s multicloud positioning may mitigate antitrust scrutiny.
- Google Cloud holds a 12% market share compared to AWS’s 30% and Azure’s 21%, prompting the emphasis on multicloud offerings.
- Google Cloud CEO Thomas Kurian emphasized the importance of multicloud capabilities to prevent customer lock-in and meet existing IT investments.

items.title: Nvidia announces new GPUs at GTC 2025, including Vera Rubin
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Nvidia announced new GPUs at GTC 2025, including the Vera Rubin, set for release in late 2026.
- Vera Rubin will feature tens of terabytes of memory and a custom CPU, Vera, with performance uplifts for AI tasks.
- Rubin can manage up to 50 petaflops for inference, surpassing the current Blackwell chips.
- Blackwell Ultra is slated for release in the second half of 2025, offering 20 petaflops with increased memory.
- Future releases include Rubin Ultra in 2027 and Feynman GPUs around 2028, also featuring a Vera CPU.

items.title: Tesla and Rivian charging networks have fewest problems by far, according to Consumer Reports
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- Tesla and Rivian charging networks are the most problem-free according to a Consumer Reports survey.
- Surveyed 1,230 EV owners between March 2024 and February 2025; only 4% reported problems with Tesla's Superchargers and 5% with Rivian's chargers.
- Shell's Recharge network had a 48% problem rate, followed by EVgo (43%) and Blink (41%).
- Common issues involved payment processing and charging hardware problems, particularly with screen malfunctions.
- Shift towards electric vehicles continues, with EVs making up over 8% of U.S. vehicle sales last year.

items.title: Bolt’s former CEO is launching a new e-commerce startup
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Maju Kuruvilla, former CEO of Bolt, is launching a new startup called Spangle AI.
- Spangle AI focuses on creating custom landing pages for online shoppers, powered by an AI model named ProductGPT.
- The startup raised a $6 million seed round last year and aims to improve conversion rates for its retail clients, achieving a 51% boost in early tests.

items.title: Pebble creator unveils the first new Pebble-inspired smartwatches
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Eric Migicovsky introduced two new smartwatches, the Core 2 Duo and the Core Time 2, as spiritual successors to the original Pebble smartwatches.
- The watches are available for pre-order at prices of $149 and $225, respectively.
- Pebble, known for its successful Kickstarter campaign in 2012, sold over two million devices before shutting down in 2016 and was acquired by Fitbit.
- Core Devices, led by Migicovsky, is reviving the Pebble brand with new models running on PebbleOS, which Google open-sourced for community use.
- The Core 2 Duo features a non-touch E Ink display and promises up to 30 days of battery life.
- Shipments for the Core 2 Duo are expected to start in July 2025, and the Core Time 2 will be available in December 2025.

items.title: Stability AI’s new AI model turns photos into 3D scenes
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Stability AI has launched the Stable Virtual Camera, an AI model that converts 2D images into immersive 3D videos.
- The model allows generation of novel views from one or more images (up to 32) with various camera angles.
- It supports multiple dynamic camera paths like 'Spiral', 'Dolly Zoom', 'Move', and 'Pan', with aspect ratios of 1:1, 9:16, and 16:9.
- The technology is available for research under a non-commercial license from Hugging Face.
- Stability AI, known for its model Stable Diffusion, recently underwent management changes and financial restructuring.

items.title: How to watch Nvidia GTC 2025, including CEO Jensen Huang’s keynote
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Nvidia’s GTC conference began Monday, with major announcements expected Tuesday.
- CEO Jensen Huang’s keynote scheduled for Tuesday at 10 a.m. PT, available for live streaming at Nvidia.com and on their YouTube channel.
- Anticipated topics include the Blackwell Ultra GPU series, next-gen Rubin chip architecture, automotive advancements, robotics, AI updates, and a special focus on quantum computing.

items.title: Google brings a ‘canvas’ feature to Gemini, plus Audio Overview
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Google has introduced a new feature called Canvas to its Gemini AI chatbot, enabling users to collaborate on writing and coding projects.
- Canvas allows for interactive editing, tone adjustment, and real-time code previews, similar to OpenAI's Canvas for ChatGPT.
- In addition to Canvas, Google has added the Audio Overview feature from NotebookLM, offering audio summaries of documents and content.
- Both features are available for free to Gemini users globally, with some limitations on code previews and language for audio summaries.

items.title: CISA scrambles to contact fired employees after court rules layoffs ‘unlawful’
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- The U.S. government’s cybersecurity agency, CISA, is trying to reach over 130 former employees after a court ruling deemed their layoffs 'unlawful'.
- U.S. District Judge James Bredar ordered reinstatement of employees fired by the Trump administration, particularly probationary workers hired within the last three years.
- CISA had previously cut 130 probationary employees in February, during a federal workforce reduction.
- The agency lacks contact information for all affected employees and is urging those impacted to reach out directly.
- Re-hired employees will be placed on administrative leave with full pay and benefits as per CISA's new directive.

items.title: Al Gore’s Just Climate fund raises $175M from Microsoft and CalSTRS for nature-based climate investments
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Just Climate has raised $175 million from Microsoft’s Climate Innovation Fund and CalSTRS.
- The fund will focus on nature-based climate solutions like farming and forestry.
- Only $35 billion was invested in nature-based solutions in 2022, compared to $1.46 trillion for other climate finance.
- Nature-based solutions can address about 15% of annual global emissions.
- Microsoft invested in a startup called Chestnut Carbon for reforestation projects.
- Just Climate’s first investment was in NatureMetrics, which surveys biodiversity using environmental DNA (eDNA).

items.title: Anthropic-backed AI-powered code review platform Graphite raises cash
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Graphite raised $52 million in a Series B funding round led by Accel, with participation from Anthropic’s Anthology Fund, Menlo Ventures, and others.
- Founded in 2020 by Tomas Reimers, Greg Foster, and Merrill Lutsky, Graphite initially focused on mobile development tools before pivoting to code review.
- The platform uses AI to provide feedback on code, suggest code changes, and summarize code, with plans to launch a new AI tool named Diamond for automatic bug detection.
- Graphite's revenue grew 20x in 2024, serving over 500 companies including Shopify, Snowflake, and Figma, and has made its core code review tool free for teams of all sizes.

items.title: Arcade raises $12M from Perplexity co-founder’s new fund to make AI agents less awful
items.author: Alex Salazar, Sam Partee, Andy Konwinski, Pete Sonsini
items.summary:
- Arcade, an AI agent infrastructure startup, raised $12 million from Laude Ventures, a fund founded by Perplexity co-founder Andy Konwinski.
- Founded by Alex Salazar (former Okta exec) and Sam Partee (former Redis engineer) in February 2024, the startup aims to improve the functionality of AI agents.
- The company addresses issues with existing AI agents that often do not work effectively due to reliance on public data rather than private data.
- Arcade offers a tool-calling platform that allows AI agents to access apps and data with user-like privileges, integrating with OAuth for secure token management.

items.title: Mark Zuckerberg says that Meta’s Llama models have hit 1B downloads
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced that the Llama AI model family has reached 1 billion downloads, a 53% increase from 650 million in December 2024.
- Llama powers Meta AI across platforms like Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp and is available for free under a proprietary license.
- Despite its success, Llama faces challenges, including an AI copyright lawsuit and data privacy concerns leading to cancellations of launch plans in Europe.
- Meta plans to invest up to $80 billion in AI projects this year and aims to release new Llama models, including reasoning and multimodal capabilities, in the upcoming months.

items.title: Make your choice! Vote for the speaker you want to see at TechCrunch Sessions: AI
Coreshell has a plan to slash the price of American made batteries
Anthropic is reportedly prepping a voice mode for Claude
WhatsApp will soon limit number of broadcast messages users and businesses can send
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- WhatsApp will limit the number of broadcast messages that users and businesses can send to reduce spam.
- Testing will begin soon, with a suggested limit of 30 messages per month for individual users.
- Business accounts will see the introduction of a paid version for broadcast messaging, previously unlimited.
- Merchants will be able to send customized broadcast messages and schedule them, with 250 free messages available during the pilot.
- The changes aim to help users receive fewer overwhelming messages while still allowing businesses to communicate effectively.
- WhatsApp Business has become an important revenue source for Meta, with the new limits introducing a potential additional revenue stream for the company.

items.title: Exist is a new social wellness app that wants to help middle-age users find community
items.author: Jason Jardim, Alicia Waldner
items.summary:
- Exist is an iOS social wellness app aimed at helping middle-aged users connect and build communities.
- The app features social journaling, daily mood tracking, audio exercises, and guided meditations.
- Founded by Jason Jardim and Alicia Waldner, it originally targeted Gen Z but shifted focus to middle-aged users as the average sign-up age became 40.
- Exist includes a TikTok-like feed for sharing journal entries and receiving community responses.
- Offers a free community journaling experience, with a subscription option for additional features at $5.99 per month.
- Future plans include enhancing human connection, adding sleep habit tracking, and personalized journal prompts.

items.title: Google plans to release new ‘open’ AI models for drug discovery
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Google announced the development of new open AI models called TxGemma for drug discovery at a health-focused event in New York.
- The models will be released through its Health AI Developer Foundations program later this month.
- TxGemma can analyze both text and the structures of therapeutic entities, aiding researchers in predicting properties of new therapies.
- There is no clarification yet on whether the models will allow for commercial use or customization.
- The move follows a trend where many companies are investing in AI for drug research but face challenges in clinical trial success.
- Over 460 AI startups are working on drug discovery, with $60 billion invested in the space so far.

items.title: Google launches new healthcare-related features for Search, Android
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
• Google announced new healthcare-related features for Search, including expanded knowledge panels for health queries.
• A new mobile feature called 'What People Suggest' highlights user-generated content about health conditions.
• Google launched new medical records APIs globally for its Health Connect platform to streamline health data access.
• The Pixel Watch 3 will introduce a 'Loss of Pulse Detection' feature by the end of March, pending FDA clearance.
• Google is set to release new open AI models for drug discovery named TxGemma in the coming weeks.

items.title: TurinTech reveals $20M in backing to fix problems in ‘vibe coding’
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- TurinTech has raised $20 million to launch its Artemis product at NVIDIA’s GTC event.
- Artemis is an ‘evolutionary AI’ platform aimed at optimizing and validating enterprise codebases, addressing inefficiencies in AI-generated code.
- The funding includes a $15 million Series A, led by Oxford Capital, with previous seed funding of $5 million.
- AI-generated code is predicted to transform software development, with Gartner projecting that 75% of enterprise software engineers will use AI code assistants by 2028.

items.title: Apple loses appeal against Germany’s special abuse control for Big Tech
items.summary:
- Apple has lost an appeal regarding Germany’s special abuse control regime enforced by the competition watchdog.
- The ruling by Germany’s Federal Court of Justice maintains the five-year regulatory designation on Apple initiated in April 2023.
- The special abuse controls aim to ensure fair competition against major digital companies, including Apple, Google, Meta, and Microsoft.
- Apple disputes the court's decision, asserting that it operates in a competitive environment and emphasizes its commitment to user privacy.

items.title: Google is buying Wiz for $33B to beef up in cloud security, sources say
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Google is acquiring cloud security startup Wiz for $33 billion, marking its largest acquisition to date.
- The deal awaits regulatory approval; neither Google nor Wiz has confirmed it officially yet.
- The acquisition is aimed at enhancing Google's position in enterprise cloud and security sectors, where it currently lags behind competitors like AWS and Microsoft Azure.
- Previous acquisition talks at a $23 billion valuation fell apart due to antitrust concerns and issues related to Wiz's autonomy.
- Wiz's business is growing rapidly, with an ARR projected to reach $1 billion this year after surpassing $500 million last year.

items.title: Nerdio nabs $500M to power virtual desktops on Azure
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- Nerdio raises $500 million in Series C funding to enhance Microsoft cloud technology management.
- Valuation has more than quadrupled since Series B, now estimated above $1 billion.
- The company targets optimization of cloud infrastructure and costs for enterprises.
- Investors include General Atlantic, Lead Edge Capital, and Stepstone, with the founders retaining a significant stake.
- Plans to expand product offerings and workforce of currently 300 employees to support growth.

items.title: YC-backed food supply startup Vendease restructures employees’ salaries
items.summary:
- Vendease, a Y Combinator-backed Nigerian food procurement startup, has changed its pay structure to a performance-based system after laying off 44% of its workforce.
- The new compensation model includes a five-phase salary recovery plan, aiming for full salary restoration by December 2025 based on performance targets.
- Vendease is seeking fresh capital and aims to become profitable by leveraging its software-driven operations and a buy now, pay later (BNPL) product to support food businesses.

items.title: GrubMarket raises $50M at a $3.5B+ valuation to build AI for the $1 trillion food distribution industry
items.summary:
- GrubMarket secured $50 million in a Series G funding round, boosting its valuation to over $3.5 billion.
- Major investors include Liberty Street Funds, 3Spoke Capital, and others, with a focus on technology improvements, especially in AI.
- The company anticipates $2.4 billion in revenue for 2025, up from $2 billion in 2024, and is profitable on an EBITDA basis.
- GrubMarket plans acquisitions to enhance its food distribution capabilities and has expanded its presence to 70 countries.

items.title: Google, Speedinvest back Kenya’s Leta, which uses AI to make logistics cheaper
items.summary:
- African businesses pay up to four times the global average to transport goods, driving up prices for essentials.
- Nairobi-based Leta uses AI for optimizing delivery routes, tracking shipments, and streamlining payments.
- Leta raised $5 million in seed funding led by Speedinvest, backed by Google’s Africa Investment Fund.
- The startup aims to help businesses move goods cheaper and faster across Kenya, Nigeria, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe.
- Its platform can automate manifest creation and dynamically optimize delivery routes in real-time.
- Leta has seen growth from 500,000 deliveries to 4.5 million, increasing its revenue fivefold since last coverage.

items.title: Waymo’s milestone SFO mapping permit comes with strings attached
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Waymo has received a temporary permit to map roadways at San Francisco International Airport, starting from March 14.
- Employees will manually drive Waymo vehicles for mapping; this is the first step toward commercial operations.
- The permit includes a data-sharing agreement requiring Waymo to provide specific data after mapping sessions
- Waymo is prohibited from using autonomous vehicles for moving commercial goods; this aligns with past efforts to ensure job safety and community impact.
- The temporary permit comes after Waymo's failed attempt to secure mapping rights in 2023 and requires a subsequent approval to operate commercially at SFO.

items.title: Google revives talks to acquire Wiz at higher valuation
items.author: Marina Temkin, Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Google’s parent company Alphabet is in advanced talks to acquire Wiz at a higher valuation of around $30 billion.
- The previous deal talks were at a $23 billion valuation but fell through.
- Wiz, a cloud cybersecurity startup, has annual recurring revenue of $500 million and aims for $1 billion by 2025.
- The deal is complicated by whether Wiz will remain a separate division or be integrated into Google Cloud.
- Regulatory scrutiny under the Biden administration previously contributed to the breakdown of talks.
- Wiz was founded in 2020 by former Israeli military officers and has significant backers including Andreessen Horowitz and Sequoia.
